title: How to Eat Avocado for Breakfast

methods.name: Using Avocado as a Topping or Side

steps.headline: Make avocado toast for a simple, satisfying breakfast.
steps.description: Mash the fruit from half an avocado with a drizzle of olive oil and a spritz of lemon juice, then spread it onto a piece of toast fresh out of the toaster oven. The creamy avocado and warm, crunchy toast make a combination that’s hard to beat. If you want to simplify things even more, just sprinkle your avocado toast with sea salt and cracked black pepper and dig in. Try topping your toast with red pepper flakes and a squirt of Sriracha or your personal favorite hot sauce for a spicy kick.

steps.headline: Put avocado on a savory bagel to add flavor and color.
steps.description: Layer your bagel with herbed cream cheese, smoked salmon, red onion, and sliced or mashed avocado. Or try unique another unique combination, like gruyere, heirloom tomatoes, avocado, and bean sprouts. You can put just about anything on a bagel, so get creative. It’s all fair game! Bagels can also make great breakfast sandwiches. Just add an egg and your breakfast meat of choice and put a top on it. Toast your bagel under the broiler for a couple minutes before adding your toppings to give it a satisfying crunch.

steps.headline: Mix avocado into a bean and rice bowl for a Southwest-inspired meal.
steps.description: Start with a base of steamed brown or zesty cilantro rice, then ladle on a generous serving of black beans. On top of that, pile diced avocado, tomatoes, corn, and a small handful of feta or shredded jack cheese. Finish with a spoonful of pico de gallo, cilantro, and a squeeze of lime. Sprinkle on some tortilla strips (or use crushed chips instead) to give your breakfast bowl a little extra crunch. If you’re trying to cut carbs or consume more lean protein, try substituting quinoa for ordinary rice.

steps.headline: Serve avocado plain as a nutrient-packed side.
steps.description: Of course, you don’t need to dress avocado up in order to enjoy it with the first meal of the day. Simply halve an avocado, cut the fruit inside into thin slices, and serve the slices alongside the rest of your breakfast. You’ll get all creamy goodness without masking the flavor or having to go through a bunch of complicated prep. Since avocado is so mild, it’s just as good when savored with fruits and pastries as it is with savory ingredients.

methods.name: Incorporating Avocado into Your Favorite Breakfast Foods

steps.headline: Add avocado to an omelette to make your eggs more interesting.
steps.description: While your eggs are cooking, cut half an avocado into slices or dice it into cubes. Throw the avocado into the pan along with other omelette staples like spinach, mushrooms, bell peppers, and melty cheese, then fold the eggs over to create scrumptious little pouch packed with protein, healthy fats, and good cholesterol. For a more filling breakfast, load your omelette up with slices of crispy bacon or crumbled sausage (chorizo pairs especially well with avocado).

steps.headline: Roll avocado up into a breakfast burrito for an easy handheld feast.
steps.description: Fill a large flour tortilla with scrambled eggs and cheese, along with crumbled bacon or sausage, a couple spoonfuls of salsa, and an assortment of other tasty toppings. Add a healthy amount of avocado and serve your burrito with blue corn chips, or scarf it down on your way out the door. If you’re aiming for something a little lighter, use only the egg whites and leave plenty of room for all-natural goodies like tomatoes, spinach, sweet potatoes, onion, and bell peppers.

steps.headline: Jazz up traditional huevos rancheros with avocado.
steps.description: Nestle over-easy fried eggs and wedges of sliced avocado onto a bed of warm, pillowy corn tortillas and spoon hot salsa over the top. The avocado will lend a hint of color and a bright, tangy taste, putting a festive twist on a morning classic. If you’ve got an army of hungry mouths to feed, try layering each of your components in a baking dish and turning it into a casserole.

steps.headline: Bake avocado onto a breakfast pizza for a fun way to start the day.
steps.description: Brush your pizza crust with olive oil, then add a layer of scrambled eggs, crumbled bacon, diced avocado, and any other veggies you like. Sprinkle your pizza with gooey mozzarella or tangy cheddar or jack cheese and heat it in the oven at 400 °F (204 °C) until the cheese just begins to brown. If you’re vegetarian or vegan, swap out the eggs, cheese, and meat for your favorite plant-based substitutes, or pile on extra veggies in their place. Grabbing a ready-to-bake pizza crust from the grocery store will help cut down on your prep time. If you’re cooking for the sake of enjoyment, you can also try making your own dough from scratch.

steps.headline: Put your leftovers to good use in an avocado-filled breakfast hash.
steps.description: A traditional hash is made by frying up leftover meat with diced or shredded potatoes, onion, and sometimes eggs and cheese, all in the same skillet. For your version, avocado will serve as one of the primary ingredients, and you can use more or less of the other components as you see fit. Chorizo, black beans, sliced jalapeños, and pico de gallo all make great additions to a breakfast hash featuring avocado. A handful of shredded cheese can add extra flavor and help your hash hold together better.

methods.name: Making Avocado Part of a Healthy Breakfast

steps.headline: Bake an egg in an avocado for your daily dose of protein and good fats.
steps.description: Slice a ripe avocado in half and remove the pit from each portion. Then, crack an egg into the depression left behind by the pit and sprinkle both avocados with salt, pepper, and fine-cut parsley or chives. Stick the whole thing into an oven preheated to 425 °F (218 °C) for 15-20 minutes, or until the egg is done to your liking. Feel free to add other tasty toppings to your avocado, such as cheese, fresh homemade salsa, or a spoonful of Hollandaise sauce. Baked egg-and-avocado can make a quick, easy, and nutritious breakfast for 2 when you’re short on time.

steps.headline: Blend avocado into a smoothie to lend an extra creamy texture.
steps.description: Throw a half or whole avocado into the blender with 1-2 bananas, 1 cup (240 mL) of milk, and about 8 ice cubes. Blend the ingredients together on high-power until the ice is completely broken up and there are no large pieces of fruit remaining, then drink up. Try whipping up different smoothies using an assortment of other fruits and veggies such as strawberries, blueberries, kiwi, mango, and kale. It’s important that you use ripe avocados in order to make sure your smoothie comes out nice and creamy.

steps.headline: Enhance carb-heavy pancake or waffle batter with avocado.
steps.description: Whisk 1/4 cup (48 g) of mashed avocado and ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of coconut oil together with 1.5 cups (350 mL) of buttermilk and 2 whole large eggs to prepare the wet ingredients for your batter. Transfer your wet ingredients to a large mixing bowl containing 1.5 cups (180 g) of all-purpose flour, 1 tablespoon (12 g) of sugar, 1.5 teaspoons (6 g) of baking powder, and 1/4 teaspoon (1 g) of baking soda and whisk the batter until it’s smooth and free of lumps. If you’re a gluten-free eater (or just counting calories), you can also make a simple 5-ingredient version of this recipe using 1 mashed avocado, 1 mashed banana, 1 cup (90 g) of oats, 1 egg, and a splash of unsweetened almond milk.

steps.headline: Prepare avocado power bars to eat on the run if you're short on time.
steps.description: Slice, pit, and peel an avocado and run it through the food processor with 1 cup (150 g) of pitted dates and 1 cup (150 g) of almonds until they’re uniformly chunky. Sift in 1/2 cup (45 g) of shredded coconut and 1/4 cup (30 g) each of chia seeds and cocoa powder and process again to thoroughly mix the ingredients. Spread the mixture into a nonstick baking dish and chill it for 2-3 hours before cutting it into squares. If you want to pack even more flavor into your power bars, you can also add 1/2 cup (75 g) of shelled sunflower seeds and/or 1/4 cup (40 g) of miniature chocolate chips. Power bars are a convenient grab-and-go breakfast if you’re on a special diet or you just don’t have time to put together a full meal at home.

steps.headline: Use avocado in place of less healthy fats in your baked goods.
steps.description: Rather than reaching for the butter the next time you’re getting a batch of muffins, brownies, or scones ready for the oven, try stirring in an equal amount of mashed avocado. The oily fruit will provide the same rich texture as butter or shortening with up to 40% less saturated fat! Avocado doesn’t coat quite as well as softened butter, so you may need to use slightly more of your wet ingredients to make up the textural difference. Reduce the temperature of the oven by about 25 °F (−4 °C) if you’re substituting 100% of your fats. This will keep the avocado from browning too fast and impacting the color and flavor of the finished confection.
